p.s: The given excerpt from the novel The Great Gatsby, that was written by F. Scott Fitzgerald and published in 1925, tells Gatsby's and Daisy Buchanan's reunion from Nick Carraway's narrative perspective.
Compared to prior chapters and taking into consideration how Jay Gatsby was presented in them, there is no doubt that his personality is drastically different in this scene.
The most important aspect, that characterizes Gatsby in this particular scene, is his obvious nervousness when being around Daisy Buchanan.
Nick's narrative perspective provides many examples, in which Jay Gatsby is clearly nervous and perhaps even uncomfortable.
A very obvious example would be his constant use of exaggerations, in order to dramatise the situation at hand.
He uses these exaggerations, when Gatsby shows up at his door after having fled the living room in fear and worry of having to reunite with Daisy.
In this moment Nick describes Gatsby's apparence as pale as death (p. 84, l. 14) and refers to his glance as tragic (p. 84, l. 16).

The use of the words death and tragically in the same sentence remindreminds the reader of tragedy and death, which allows the reader to comprehend the suffering of Gatsby as well as the drama and the gravity of the scene.
Gatsby's nervousness is also highlighted through other factors, such as him almost making the clock fall.
This is a sign of clumsiness, that we have not seen in any previous chapters (p. 85, l. 5-7).
If you put Gatsby's behavior in this in contrast to his behavior in prior chapters, you will be able to see a meaningful change.
For one, he was depicted as a confident person, as he didn't care about the assumptions being made about him behind his back (p. 64 l. 26-27).

Yet in this scene, he's not only the complete opposite as he is clearly nervous which you can tell by his running out on Daisy (p. 84 l. 9-10) or by keeping his hands in his pockets the entire time (p. 84 l. 27), but he also shows that he cares about what Daisy thinks of him.

As he invites her to take a look at his house it is perfectly clear that he wants her to like the house (p. 87 l. 25-26), yet as I mentioned before, he has never seemed to care about other peoplespeople's opinion of him before.
It is also said in a previous chapter, that Gatsby is a man who picks his words with care (p. 50 l. 9-10).
Comparing that characterisation of Gatsby to his way of acting in this particular excerpt, there is a clear difference, as Gatsby doesn't seem to talk much at all.

All throughout the excerpt there are pauses that endure horribly (p. 84 l. 25), as well as a lot of silence: I felt that silence had fallen within the house too (p. 87 l. 5-6), set us all back for at least another minute (p. 85 l. 18-19).
Gatsby's incapability to pick any words, let alone with care, once again highlights his change in character and his nervousness.

Although there are plenty of differences between Gatsby in other chapters and Gatsby in this specific excerpt, there also happen to be some things, that these two characterizations of Gatsby have in common.
A fairly obvious example would be his shyness or him being a quiet person.
As mentioned beforehand, Gatsby does not talk a lot in this scene, as it is dominated by silence and pauses.

And eventhough there are high expectations for Jay Gatsby, as so many people speculate about him, Nick characterizes Gatsby in the following way: I had talked with him perhaps half a dozen times in the past month and found, to my disappointment, that he had little to say (p. 64 l. 12-14).

This quotation from a previous chapter, shows how Gatsby being quiet is not something, that is brought upon by Daisy or newly introduced in this scene, but that it's just part of his character and has been for a few chapters.
However once Gatsby get'sgets to know a person and actually feels comfortable around them, he tends to be very open and share a lot of thoughts, feelings or stories.
This can be seen in chapter 4, as Gatsby opens up about his past, as well as traumatic experiences (p. 65 l. 9).
He is also open about his feelings in this scene, as he voices his doubts about reuniting with Daisy to Nick, by sayinsaying This is a terrible mistake (p. 86 l. 1).
Apart from that, he also opens up to Daisy at the end of the excerpt.
By the end of the chapter Nick finds Daisy and Gatsby in the living room as Daisy is crying.
However later on it is revealed, that Daisy is crying out of joy, as Nick says: Her throat, full of aching, grieving and beauty, told only of her unexpected joy (p. 87 l. 23-24).
Taking into consideration, that after being left alone with Gatsby, Daisy came out crying tears of joy, it can be speculated, that Gatsby must've opened up his heart to her.
Nick's narrative perspective is very helpful and contributes a lot to Gatsby's characterisation.
An important moment, that takes place in the given excerpt, that also shows how helpful Nick's narrative perspective is, is the scene in which Gatsby starts having second thoughts.
In this scene Gatsby decides to voice these to Nick, as he considers him a friend.
Had the story not been narrated by Nick, we might not have been able to feel Gatsby's doubts and worries in such a comfortable space.
Another important aspect of the chosen narrative perspective, is the effect of mystery.

Since this scene is told through Nick's perspective, the reader has no way of knowing, what Daisy and Gatsby talked about in private, which is very important in order to keep a certain mystery and to intrigue the reader.

In conclusion it is fairly obvious, that Gatsby's character goes through a lot of changes in personality in the given excerpt, yet he stays true to many characteristics, that he had in previous chapters.
This leads to the conclusion, that these significant changes are brought upon by Daisy Buchanan's presence.
